newsitem.title: USA: U.S. backs Croatian radio station 101.
newsitem.headline: U.S. backs Croatian radio station 101.

text.p: U.S. relations with Croatia could suffer if independent Croatian Radio 101 is forced off the air, a State Department spokesman said on Friday.
"This is the premiere independent voice in the country as we understand it. And we believe it ought to stay on the air," spokesman Glyn Davies told reporters.
"The United States, as you know, believes that Radio 101 should have its license renewed at the same frequency or a comparable frequency to the very good frequency that it has."
Asked if closing Radio 101 could adversely affect U.S. relations with Croatia, he replied, "it might well," but would not be more specific. "I don't want to speculate too broadly," he said.

A government-controlled telecommunications council on Wednesday failed to grant the radio a broadcasting license. But after a rally by 100,000 people on Thursday night in a Zagreb square, authorities annulled the decision and said a new tender would be opened.

"We believe that the Croatian State Broadcasting Council's decision delaying action to take Radio 101 off the air is a step in the right direction. We don't believe that it goes far enough. They should be granted license and kept on the air," Davies said. He said Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott and U.S. Embassy officials in Zagreb have had discussions with Croatian officials on behalf of Radio 101.
